ğ’†¸ KAR [KUR](KUR.html)  

ğ“‚“ â‰  ğ“Š– â€œKarâ€ is likely the most recognisable international sign cluster in the age of urbanization and syllabic writing from the 4th millennium BC. It combines a wonderword with a kind of wondersign, akin to the spread of alphabets throughout many cultures:  

ğ’†³ kur ĞºĞ°Ğ¹Ğ° ğ’†  ki ğ”—œ ku ğœº	KU ğ˜¾ ka ğ€ KA ğ‘£ ĞºĞµÑ€Ğ»Ğ° ğ”•† â€¢KAR ğ”•ˆ KA ğ”•‡ ğ€¤ ğ˜¿ QE ğŠ¨ Ê˜ q /kÊ·/ â°– Uku ğ’‰½ KURâ‚‚ ğ‘€“ KA ğ’„¯ á¸ªar ğ“Š– [1] ğ’ƒ¸ kÃ¡r ğ’ƒ¼ gar  
ğ““ ğ“Š– ğœ°¸ ğœ°´ ğ’†  perfect continuum in [Indus](Indus.html) script, though its value so far is unproven.  

It combines two similar sounding concepts, Kreuz and Kreis ([cross](cross.html) and [circle](circle.html)) or Kreuz and Karos (cross and squares) into a very persistant phonetic and logographic unit of "KAR".  

â€œKarâ€ has two main semantic meanings "[city](city.html)" and "[mountain](mountain.html)", connected through the concept of [tell](tell.html) (city-hill). Later also via extension: "country". Connections to "cold" and "stone" may be secondary or basal but not part of the logographic KAR cluster under investigation.  

ğŠ” Naturally associated with the number [4](4.html) (sometimes ğŠ¼ [3](3.html) or [Ï€](Ï€.html) ), semantically via city court quarters, also supporting the "kar" root in some branches.  

Traces of this sign or its underlying wanderword can be seen on any atlas: From Novgorod via Merhgarh, Ankara, Sakkara to english courts. As with many wanderwords as part of names, this very recognizable pre-/suffix is still all too often [reanalized](reanalized.html) per instance by folk etymologies and [Bad-Linguistics](Bad-Linguistics.html).  

Representatives of Kar can have all vowels a,e,i,o,u,â€¦, so labeling this cluster 'Kar' is somewhat arbitrary, K-R would be more fitting. For extended discussion of connections between this well defined group and other far reaching concepts see [KUR](KUR.html)!  

Representatives of Kar are visible in near all logographich systems.  

ğ’†³ kur ğ’†  ki ğ”—œ ku ğœº	KU ğ˜¾ ka ğ€ KA ğ‘£ ĞºĞµÑ€Ğ»Ğ° ğ”•† â€¢KAR ğ”•ˆ KA ğ”•‡ ğ€¤ ğ˜¿ QE ğŠ¨ Ê˜ q ğ’‰½ KURâ‚‚ ğ’„¯ á¸ªar ğ“Š– [1] ğœº å£ kÇ’u => å›½ êµ­ guk  

The phonetic R ğ”–± of ğ”•† KAR is often omitted in syllabic practice, reduced to ğ”•ˆ KA, just as only the 'be' of beta (Î²) is used in alphabetic usage.  

Phonetics inside and outside the syllabaries were far from stable though:  
Especially words for [city](city.html) (or related signs) corroded from kar > car > Å¡ar sar > á¸«ar > har via common [sound-change](sound-change.html) chains. On the other hand it might have been reattached conciously to similar concepts and variants.  

[1]:  
ğ“Š– had probably many phonetic readings over time, but symbollically it fits the above description of Kar perfectly!!  
ğ“Š– does have indirect evidence for repesenting the KAR/court cluster though: ğ“ ğ“‹“ ğ“‚‹ ğ“ ğ“ ğ“€ even if via [complement](complement.html).  
ğ“ fits phonetically but has no city connotation, unlike similar ğ“Š–.  
ğ“Š¨ may be an imperfect specimen without circle connotations via secondary qursi â‰ˆ chair readings.  

see [KUR](KUR.html)

# [ğ“ˆ‰](ğ“ˆ‰.html) ZARD
The mountain root of the kar cluster, before it became to mean tellâ‰ˆcity/court can be reconstructed as  
KAR<CAR<ZARD>TSAR>TAR
